notes.title: Definition, Scope & Four Fields of Anthropology
notes.content: Define anthropology; distinguish from sociology, political science, economics. Outline four fields (cultural, biological, linguistic, archaeology) and integrative holism. Map recurring exam asks (2016–19; 2021–24) on definition/scope/relations with other social sciences.
keyTakeaways: Use clear, exam-ready definitions and contrasts.
Show how the four fields interrelate (e.g., biocultural).
Cite contemporary applications in policy and development.

resources.title: Perspectives: An Open Invitation to Cultural Anthropology (2nd Ed.)

notes.title: Culture: Concepts, Characteristics & Adaptive/Maladaptive Change
notes.content: Define culture as learned, shared, symbolic; discuss integration, dynamism, adaptation vs. maladaptation; link to enculturation and cognition (2020–24 repeats).
keyTakeaways: Use examples of adaptive/maladaptive traits.
Connect enculturation and cognitive schemas.
Prepare short notes on culture's attributes.

notes.title: Ethnocentrism vs. Cultural Relativism
notes.content: Define ethnocentrism and cultural relativism; show methodological use (suspending judgment) vs. ethical debates. Frequent short notes (2016, 2022–23).
keyTakeaways: Differentiate methodological vs. moral relativism.
Use Miner's 'Nacirema' to demonstrate defamiliarization.
Anchor Boas's role in introducing relativism.

resources.title: Horace Miner — Body Ritual among the Nacirema (PDF)

notes.title: Religion & Evolution: Tylor's Animism and Beyond
notes.content: Explain Tylor's definition of religion and animism; outline evolutionary sequence; contrast with Durkheim, Geertz's interpretive approach. Recurs almost annually.
keyTakeaways: Define animism succinctly; cite Tylor.
Compare evolutionary vs. functional/interpretive theories.
Apply to 'primitive religion' and contemporary belief.

notes.title: Social Change & Applied Anthropology
notes.content: Map barriers to change, diffusion, acculturation; outline applied anthropology in health, development, urban issues; link to Pakistan's social problems.
keyTakeaways: Contrast planned vs. unplanned change.
Use caselets from development/health programs.
Explain anthropologist's role in policy design.

notes.title: Research Design: Qualitative vs. Quantitative; Objectivity vs. Subjectivity
notes.content: Compare methods; operationalize concepts; discuss reflexivity, positionality and epistemological debates. Frequent 2016–24.
keyTakeaways: Define technique vs. method vs. methodology.
Show mixed-methods triangulation.
Use 'thick description' as model of interpretive rigor.

notes.title: Kinship Basics: Descent, Residence & Terminologies
notes.content: Define consanguine/affine, unilineal vs. bilateral descent, patrilineal/matrilineal, residence patterns (virilocal/uxorilocal), lineage vs. clan; connect to politics and property.
keyTakeaways: Draw quick kinship charts for exam.
Explain links to inheritance and alliance.
Use Pakistan examples (biradari).

resources.title: ScienceDirect — Consanguineous Marriage in Rural Pakistan (abstract)

notes.title: Family & Marriage Systems
notes.content: Types of family (nuclear/joint/extended); marital forms (monogamy, polygyny, polyandry); levirate/sororate; functions (manifest/latent).
keyTakeaways: Link residence to authority and inheritance.
Use Islamic law context in Pakistan where relevant.
Prepare definitions for MCQs.

resources.title: OpenStax — Social Institutions (family sections across chapters)

notes.title: Economic Anthropology: Reciprocity, Redistribution & Markets
notes.content: Trace exchange forms (Polanyi) and reciprocity types (Sahlins): generalized, balanced, negative; situate 'original affluent society' debate.
keyTakeaways: Define each exchange form with examples.
Relate to social integration and inequality.
Connect to contemporary debates on markets vs. social protection.

resources.title: Trade & Market in the Early Empires (Polanyi et al.)

notes.title: Political Organization: Bands, Tribes, Chiefdoms, States; Conflict & Stratification
notes.content: Classify political forms; outline internal vs. external conflict theories; discuss stratification and mobility; connect to Pakistan's patronage and kinship politics.
keyTakeaways: Use cross-cultural typology with features (scale, leadership, law).
Explain conflict theories (Marx; internal/external).
Give examples from South Asia.

notes.title: Symbols, Meaning & Interpretation
notes.content: Explain symbol systems; Geertz's interpretive anthropology; thick description as analytic method; use rituals and meaning-making examples.
keyTakeaways: Define 'thick description' and apply to caselets.
Contrast with materialist and functionalist readings.
Useful for essay questions on meaning and culture.

resources.title: Geertz — The Interpretation of Cultures (full selection)

notes.title: Health, Religion & Society
notes.content: Intersect belief, ritual and healing; supernatural causation models; anthropology of health behaviors and programs.
keyTakeaways: Use culturally informed health program examples.
Tie to COVID-19 and risk perception (2021 exams).
Bridge religion and medical systems.

notes.title: Contemporary Pakistan: Kinship, Politics & Development
notes.content: Analyze biradari as social capital, political alignment and welfare/access mechanism; link to development interventions and governance.
keyTakeaways: Cite empirical studies on biradari and Panchayat.
Discuss pros/cons for service delivery and rights.
Relate to stratification and state capacity.

notes.title: Research Techniques: Participant Observation, Interviews, Ethics & Fieldnotes
notes.content: Operational steps for PO; combining with interviews, mapping, documents; fieldnote discipline; consent and confidentiality protocols.
keyTakeaways: Write structured, time-stamped fieldnotes.
Use triangulation and iterative sampling.
Align with AAA ethics and local IRB norms.

notes.title: Classic Theorists: Morgan, Tylor, Radcliffe-Brown, Boas
notes.content: Short profiles and exam-oriented contrasts: unilineal evolution (Morgan/Tylor) vs. historical particularism (Boas) vs. structural-functionalism (Radcliffe-Brown).
keyTakeaways: Define each paradigm and critique briefly.
Use one concise example per theorist.
Update with post-Boasian developments.

notes.title: 20th-Century Turns: Cultural Materialism, Interpretivism, Feminist & Cognitive
notes.content: Contrast Harris's cultural materialism (infrastructure → structure → superstructure) with Geertz's interpretivism; note feminist and cognitive approaches.
keyTakeaways: Be able to apply both materialist and interpretive lenses to a case.
Use concise definitions and one Pakistan example.
Flag exam MCQs on 'cultural materialism' (2024).

notes.title: Data Sources & Comparative Methods
notes.content: Use eHRAF for cross-cultural searches; code variables; run focused comparisons; beware of equivalence and context.
keyTakeaways: Code cases consistently; define operational categories.
Combine ethnography with secondary data.
Document search strings and inclusion criteria.

notes.title: Ethics & Professional Conduct
notes.content: Core ethical principles: do no harm, informed consent, transparency, data protection, reciprocity; conflicts of interest and community obligations.
keyTakeaways: Align field practice with AAA ethics.
Plan consent and anonymization upfront.
Reflect on positionality and benefit sharing.

notes.title: Exam Strategy: Repeating Patterns (2016–2019; 2020–2024)
notes.content: Prioritize high-frequency topics: religion (Tylor), kinship systems, research methods, Pakistan social issues, cultural definitions; prepare short notes (ethnocentrism, relativism, participant observation, sororate/virilocal).
keyTakeaways: Build 1-page templates for common 20-markers.
Memorize 10–12 crisp definitions for MCQs.
Include one Pakistan example per essay.

notes.title: Core Readers & Open Textbooks (Keep-on-Desk)
notes.content: Maintain a small shelf of freely accessible, exam-relevant texts for quick revision and citations.
keyTakeaways: Cite primary texts where possible (Tylor, Geertz, Polanyi, Sahlins).
Use open textbooks for structure and definitions.
Keep PDFs offline for exam prep.

resources.title: OpenStax — Introduction to Anthropology (full OER PDF)
